articles.title: How to Annul Promises in JavaScript
articles.description: You can 'cancel' XHR and fetch requests, but can you cancel regular promises? Currently, no, but Zachary looks into doing the next best thing: telling a promise the game's up, and discarding/ignoring its eventual results.
articles.author: Zachary Lee

articles.title: regex 2.1: Turn JavaScript's Regular Expression Support Up to Eleven
articles.description: From the co-author of O‚ÄôReilly‚Äôs High Performance JavaScript and Regular Expressions Cookbook comes an enhancement for JavaScript‚Äôs regex support. Supporting all of ES2024‚Äôs regex functionality, it adds support for free spacing and comments, atomic groups, regex subroutines, context-aware interpolation of RegExp instances, and more.
articles.author: Steven Levithan

articles.title: Enhancing The New York Times' Web Performance with React 18
articles.description: Last year, The New York Times set out to take full advantage of React 18 on its flagship news site. This is a tour of the challenges faced in upgrading, coupled with the significant benefits they managed to take advantage of.
articles.author: Ilya Gurevich (NYT)

articles.title: How to Use a Go(lang) Library from JavaScript with WebAssembly
articles.description: Compiling Go code to WebAssembly opens up some interesting opportunities in the browser.
articles.author: Thomas Derflinger

articles.title: How We Tamed Node.js Event Loop Lag
articles.description: Node famously uses very few threads yet can handle a large number of clients performantly, as long as the work associated with each client is ‚Äòsmall.‚Äô When that work isn't 'small', as here, things can go off the rails quickly.
articles.author: Eric Allam

articles.title: How People with Disabilities Use the Web
articles.description: Describes tools and approaches that disabled people use to interact with the Web and the barriers these people face. Of interest are the user personas that show the range of specific people‚Äôs experiences.
articles.author: W3C

articles.title: A Set of Modern Web Performance Guides
articles.description: A helpful collection of guides, covering things such as working with the different core web vitals, JavaScript optimization, metrics, and more.
articles.author: SpeedCurve

articles.title: BWIP-JS: A Barcode Writer in Pure JavaScript
articles.description: A library that can generate barcodes using over 100 different barcode types and standards, both single and two dimensional. There is, of course, a live demo where you, too, can discover far more types of barcodes exist than you ever imagined.
articles.author: Mark Warren

articles.title: Superstruct 2.0: Define Interfaces to Validate Data at Runtime
articles.description: Designed for validating data at runtime with an annotation API inspired by TypeScript, Flow, Go and GraphQL. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Ian Storm Taylor

articles.title: Termino.js 2.0: Create Terminal-Like Experiences in the Browser
articles.description: No dependencies, customizable, and you can create multiple terminal instances on a single page. Demos.
articles.author: Marketing Pipeline

articles.title: Fabric.js 6.0: A SVG-to-Canvas and Canvas-to-SVG Library
articles.description: Provides an interactive object model on top of the HTML5 canvas to make it easier to work with multiple visual elements there. The homepage is a complete live demo.
articles.author: Fabric.js

articles.title: Flitter: A Flutter-Like JavaScript Data Visualization Framework
articles.description: Boasts a declarative syntax and support for both SVG and Canvas to allow you to build high-performance data visualizations, interactive charts, diagrams, and more. It‚Äôs also easy to integrates with React, Svelte, etc.
articles.author: Flitter

articles.title: SquirrellyJS 9: A Powerful Template Engine
articles.description: A modern, configurable, and fast template engine promising ‚Äúthe power of Nunjucks‚Äù and ‚Äúthe simplicity of EJS‚Äù. There‚Äôs an online playground if you want to see it in action. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Ben Gubler

articles.title: Sliderland: A Minimalist Coding Playground
articles.description: A slider control based visualization you can code with simple formulas. We last linked to this a few years ago, but it‚Äôs still a fun way to do some quick, visual JS math experimentation. Tixy.land is along similar lines, but based on a 2D grid.
articles.author: blinry

articles.description: Nicholas C. Zakas writes about different JavaScript runtimes and how you can preserve the ability to switch runtimes easily.
The React Native team says developers building modern React Native apps should be using a framework to do so, such as Expo.
Web pioneer Marc Andreessen tells ‚ñ∂Ô∏è the origin story of Mosaic and Netscape.
ü§¶ If you can't get your Lighthouse scores to 100%, you could always pretend.. A trick to keep an eye out for..
There are at least 535 ways to reload a page with JavaScript.
Backbone.js 1.6 ‚Äì The classic library gets a little update.
Qwik 1.6 ‚Äì Qwik 2 is coming soon, though.
A raft of Node.js Security Releases are due on July 8.
ESLint 9.6, PrimeVue 4.0, Bun 1.1.18

articles.title: Web Performance Guide
articles.description: A helpful collection of over 20 plain language guides, covering things such as working with the different core web vitals, optimization techniques, critical CSS, metrics, user monitoring, and more. You‚Äôre bound to find some worthwhile advice here.
articles.author: SpeedCurve

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Layout and Reading Order
articles.description: This talk gets into the nitty gritty of layout options with CSS (think grid, subgrid, gap etc) ‚Äî with a particular focus on the proposed, new CSS masonry method, what it aims to fix and the prototyping currently underway in Chrome. A good overview of where we are, and where things are heading in terms of laying out our pages. Slides here.
articles.author: Rachel Andrew

articles.title: üêû Announcing the Ladybird Browser Initiative
articles.description: Ladybird is an in-development browser (forked from SerenityOS) that uses a brand new engine based on web standards, without borrowing any code from other browsers. It‚Äôs targeting an alpha release for both Linux and macOS in the summer of 2026 ‚Äî so is some ways off. GitHub co-founder Chris Wanstrath shares his thoughts on why the project matters.
articles.author: Ladybird Browser Initiative

articles.title: How People with Disabilities Use the Web
articles.description: Describes tools and approaches that disabled people use to interact with technology and the barriers that people experience when accessibility is lacking. Of particular interest are the user personas which show some of the range of people‚Äôs experiences.
articles.author: W3C

articles.title: How to Use Container Queries Now
articles.description: Makes pragmatic recommendations on how we can use container queries now (whilst still supporting older browsers).
articles.author: Philip Walton

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Collaboration, the Future of CSS, Sass, and the Web with Miriam Suzanne
articles.description: Schalk Neethling sits down with Miriam Suzanne, a multifaceted expert in web development, and an invited expert to the CSS Working Group.
articles.author: Mechanical Ink podcast

articles.title: CSS 'Surprise Manga Lines'
articles.description: When a manga or anime character is surprised, lines often focus on and highlight their face. This post looks at how to create a similar effect with HTML and CSS.
articles.author: Alvaro Montoro

articles.title: Four Reasons An Overlay Widget Will Not Solve Your Accessibility¬†Woes
articles.description: Thoughts on why web accessibility overlays are ‚Äúnot a reliable solution for fixing accessibility issues‚Äù, along with some cost-effective alternatives to improve accessibility on your site.
articles.author: Matt Litzinger

articles.title: Checkboxes: Design Guidelines
articles.description: When to use them, what alternative input fields to consider, and usability guidelines to keep in mind.
articles.author: Maddie Brown

articles.title: 'Blazing Fast' Websites with Speculation Rules
articles.description: A look at how to pre-render pages on your site. There‚Äôs a demo included to so you can get a feel for how it works.
articles.author: Umar Hansa

articles.title: Text-Reveal Effect Using conic-gradient() in CSS
articles.description: A thorough explanation of a neat CSS technique for revealing text.
articles.author: Preethi Sam

articles.title: Flitter: A Flutter-Like JavaScript Data Visualization Framework
articles.description: Boasts a declarative syntax and support for both SVG and Canvas to allow you to build high-performance data visualizations, interactive charts, diagrams, and more. It‚Äôs also easy to integrates with React, Svelte, etc.
articles.author: Flitter

articles.title: MSHR: A Gallery of 200+ Static and Animated CSS Mesh Gradients
articles.description: You can browse existing gradients or create your own using the online playground, which lets you ‚Äúshow points‚Äù for a more visual understanding of the gradients, among other customization features.
articles.author: mshr

articles.title: Fabric.js 6.0: A SVG-to-Canvas and Canvas-to-SVG Library
articles.description: Provides an interactive object model on top of the HTML5 canvas to make it easier to work with multiple visual elements there. The homepage is a complete live demo.
articles.author: Fabric.js

articles.title: Deblank Colors: An AI-Powered Color Palette Generator
articles.description: Enter a description of the project you‚Äôre working on to generate a color palette with options to add a preferred color or an image for a more customized result.
articles.author: Envato
